data.title: 10 Largest Cities in the U.S.
data.meta_description: Want to know where to live, work, or play? If so, then take a look at this list of the most populated cities in the U.S., and find out why people are so drawn to them.
data.text:
Population and development often go hand in hand in the very same way that population growth and the potential for future economic growth do. As such, some of the largest cities in the United States are also the most populated.

Below, you’ll find a list of the 10 most populated U.S. cities. Along with their most recently recorded population, you’ll find other relevant facts, including the median age, median household income, and estimated home/condo values. Knowing these figures makes it easy to see what cities are the most and least affordable.

Note: All figures are from 2022, the most recent Census data available, unless otherwise indicated.

Key Takeaways

Population and development are often interrelated in the same way that population growth and economic growth are related.

New York is the most populated city in the United States.

Two cities in California made the top 10 populated cities: Los Angeles and San Diego.

Texas made the list with four cities: Houston, San Antonio, Dallas, and Austin.

Chicago, Phoenix, and Philadelphia also ranked among the 10 most populated U.S. cities.

1. New York

Population: 8.34 million

Population Change Since 2020: -4.6%

Median Age: 38.4 years

Median Household Income: $76,607

Median Value of Owner-Occupied Housing Units: $732,100

Nicknames: The Big Apple, The City That Never Sleeps, The Melting Pot

Prominent Tourist Attractions: Statue of Liberty, Empire State Building, Central Park, Broadway, Times Square

2. Los Angeles

Population: 3.82 million

Population Change Since 2020: -1.89%

Median Age: 37.1 years

Median Household Income: $76,244

Median Value of Owner-Occupied Housing Units: $822,600

Nicknames: L.A., La-La Land, City of Angels

Prominent Tourist Attractions: Hollywood, Griffith Observatory, Sunset Boulevard

3. Chicago

Population: 2.7 million

Population Change Since 2020: -1.8%

Median Age: 35.8 years

Median Household Income: $65,781

Median Value of Owner-Occupied Housing Units: $297,300

Nicknames: The Windy City, the City of Big Shoulders, The Second City

Prominent Tourist Attractions: Millennium Park, Willis Tower, Navy Pier

According to the Census Bureau, the estimated population of the U.S. in 2021 was 332 million.

4. Houston

Population: 2.3 million

Population Change Since 2020: -0.6%

Median Age: 33.7 years

Median Household Income: $56,019

Median Value of Owner-Occupied Housing Units: $200,700

Nicknames: Space City, H-Town, The Big Heart

Prominent Tourist Attractions: Space Center Houston, Hermann Park, Houston Zoo

5. Phoenix

Population: 1.6 million

Population Change Since 2020: +1%

Median Age: 34.5 years

Median Household Income: $64,927

Median Value of Owner-Occupied Housing Units: $352,600

Nicknames: Valley of the Sun, The Valley

Prominent Tourist Attractions: Desert Botanical Garden, Papago Park, South Mountain Park/Preserve

6. Philadelphia

Population: 1.6 million

Population Change Since 2020: -1.7%

Median Age: 35.2 years

Median Household Income: $52,649

Median Value of Owner-Occupied Housing Units: $220,700

Nicknames: Philly, The City of Brotherly Love, The Birthplace of America, The Quaker City

Prominent Tourist Attractions: Liberty Bell, Independence Hall, Philadelphia Museum of Art

7. San Antonio

Population: 1.5 million

Population Change Since 2020: +1.2%

Median Age: 33.9 years

Median Household Income: $55,084

Median Value of Owner-Occupied Housing Units: $167,700

Nicknames: Alamo City, Countdown City, River City

Prominent Tourist Attractions: The Alamo, San Antonio River Walk, San Antonio Missions National Historical Park

Tokyo is the world’s most populated city, with more than 37 million people, followed by Delhi, India (29.4 million), and Shanghai, China (26.3 million).

8. San Diego

Population: 1.4 million

Population Change Since 2020: -0.3%

Median Age: 35.9 years

Median Household Income: $89,457

Median Value of Owner-Occupied Housing Units: $768,800

Nicknames: America’s Finest City, City in Motion, Silicon Beach

Prominent Tourist Attractions: Balboa Park, San Diego Zoo, USS Midway Museum

9. Dallas

Population: 1.3 million

Population Change Since 2020: -1.2%

Median Age: 33.7 years

Median Household Income: $58,231

Median Value of Owner-Occupied Housing Units: $267,600

Nicknames: City of Hate, D-Town, The Metroplex

Prominent Tourist Attractions: Dallas Arboretum and Botanical Garden, Klyde Warren Park, The Dallas World Aquarium

10. San Jose, CA

Population: 1 million

Population Change Since 2020: -3%

Median Age: 38.4 years

Median Household Income: $125,075

Median Value of Owner-Occupied Housing Units: $1,119,500

Nicknames: The Capital of Silicon Valley, San Jo

Prominent Tourist Attractions: San José Museum of Art, California’s Great America, Computer History Museum

Recent Demographic Trends in U.S. Cities

The last several years has seen some changes in demographics and migration trends in and out of large American cities. COVID-19, for example, created a work-at-home culture that has allowed city residents to move to the suburbs and beyond without having to commute as much as before. Many tech companies have kept their work-from-home policies even as vaccination and immunity have largely decreased the severity of COVID-19. Other companies are switching to hybrid models that allow for some time in the office.

Thus, after more than a decade of steady population growth, large cities like New York, Los Angeles, and Chicago have seen their populations drop modestly since 2020. Cities that did see continued growth tended to be more affordable cities located in warmer Sun Belt climates in the southern U.S., such as Phoenix, San Antonio, Jacksonville, Fla., and Fort Worth, Texas.

What Are the Largest U.S. Cities by Population?

The largest cities by population in the United States are New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, Houston, Phoenix, Philadelphia, San Antonio, San Diego, Dallas, and San Jose, Calif.

What Is the Largest City in the U.S.?

New York is the largest city in the U.S. by population. It had a population of more than 8.4 million, according to 2021 Census figures.

What Is the Biggest City in the U.S. by Area?

The largest city by area in the United States is Sitka, Alaska. The city spans 2,874 square miles of incorporated area.

The Bottom Line

While the size of a city’s population may point to its economic strength and growth, other factors may affect just how attractive it may be to potential residents. For instance, the cost of living can vary drastically. Cities like New York, Los Angeles, and San Diego are very costly. On the other hand, our research has found that Houston, Phoenix, San Antonio, and Dallas are among the most affordable big cities based on median household income relative to the median household/condo cost.
